name: Hollyhock
climate: Hollyhocks thrive in temperate climates with cool to mild summers and winters.
These plants prefer climates where the temperature does not drop below freezing.
They are well-suited for regions with moderate rainfall throughout the year.
Hollyhocks can adapt to both coastal climates and inland areas with good air circulation.
sunlight: Hollyhocks require full sun to thrive, needing at least 6 to 8 hours daily.
In partial shade, hollyhocks may grow but bloom less vigorously than in full sunlight.
Avoid planting hollyhocks in areas with too much shade, as this can lead to poor growth.
Direct sunlight helps hollyhocks produce vibrant and plentiful blooms throughout the season.
watering: It's important to water hollyhocks regularly, keeping the soil consistently moist.
Avoid waterlogging the soil, as hollyhocks do not thrive in overly wet conditions.
During dry spells, increase watering frequency to prevent wilting and stress.
Water hollyhocks at the base to minimize fungal diseases caused by wet foliage.
soil: Hollyhocks prefer well-drained, fertile soil enriched with organic matter.
They thrive in a soil pH range from slightly acidic to neutral for best growth.
Amending soil with compost or aged manure can greatly improve hollyhock health.
Avoid heavy clay soils that retain too much moisture and impede root development.
extra_care_tip: Regularly check hollyhocks for signs of rust, a common fungal disease affecting them.
Staking tall hollyhock stems can prevent wind damage and keep the plants upright.
